announce-v1.md.html:
# Announcement v1

We are really excited to introduce prext v1.

original

It's been less than a week since prext v1 was released, but I think prext can be officially released now. We still lack a lot, but we will make more after the official release.

# Our Goals

  1. stability.
  2. optimization.
  3. speed.
  4. weight.

# News

  1. End of create-prext-app

create-prext-app was created early and decided to create a new package instead of an update.

Now use create-prext instead of create-prext-app.

# Features

  • req, res

I tried this out with @prext/plugin-kit.We will apply this plugin to prext by default.

You can try these features in advance: @prext/plugin-kit.

export function get(req, res) {
  res.status(200).send(`Hello, ${req.query.name}`);
}
  • more options $page

We are aware of the problem of not being able to set the page only by file name.
Thus, we're going to change it so that we can set more page data via $page.

export const $page = {
  before(req, res) {
    console.log(`new request: ${req.params.slug}`);
  }
  after(req, res) {
    console.log("Done!");
  }
}

reference

  • typescript supported $page
import { Page } from 'prext';

export const $page: Page = {};

# Migration from v0.x

  1. Prext()

Prext() function has been changed to asynchronous.

import { Prext } from "prext";

- const app = Prext();
+ const app = await Prext();

# Conclusion

This is all that has been added so far. More features will be added in the future.

If you find a bug, make a pull request.

thank you😊😋😚

api-config.md.html:
# Config

# DefineConfig

Create prext.config.js or prext.config.ts to define config.

  1. Default
export default {};
  1. Using config.defineConfig ( recommended )
import { defineConfig } from 'prext/config';

export default defineConfig({
  /* config */
});
  1. Using main.defineConfig ( not recommended )
import { defineConfig } from 'prext';

export default defineConfig({
  /* config */
});

# Types

# base

  • Type: string
  • Default: .

Project root directory. (only relative path)

# routes

  • Type: string
  • Default: /pages/

Directory where page files are located.

# middlewares

  • Type: Array<Middleware>

Middlewares Array

function example(req, res, next) {
  req.message = 'Hello World';
  next();
}

export default {
  middlewares: [example],
};

# port

  • Type: number
  • Default: 5050

Port

# handler

  • Type: HandlerType

Custom Server Handler

Prext({
  handler: (req, res, routes) => {
    // ...
  },
});

# esbuild

  • Type: esbuild.BuildOptions

Esbuild build option.

# plugins

  • Type: Plugin[]

Reference: /guide/api-plugin

# watch

  • Type: chokidar.WatchOptions

api-plugin.md.html:
# Plugin

A plugin document has been created. visit here!

  1. Example Simple Plugin
// plugins/simple.ts
import { Plugin } from 'prext';

export function SimplePlugin(): Plugin {
  return {
    name: 'simple-plugin',
  };
}

// prext.config.ts
import { defineConfig } from 'prext/config';
import { SimplePlugin } from './plugins/simple';

export default defineConfig({
  plugins: [SimplePlugin()],
});
  1. custom html loader

Follow Custom Loader Guide.

  1. transform guide
export function MyPlugin(): Plugin {
  return {
    name: 'my-plugin',

    transform(id, code) {
      // id: file name
      // code: source

      return {
        // path
        // like /about, /user/hello
        file: parse(id).name,

        /*
          module.
          See - https://prext.netlify.app/guide/routing
        */
        m: {
          get(req, res) {
            res.end('Hello World!');
          },
        },
        /* 
          "build" feature requires modulePath. 
          If you don't want to support build feature, you don't have to provide this value.
        */
        modulePath: '',
        type: 'module', // html or js
      };
    },
  };
}
  1. server guide

You can apply middlewares or custom handlers.

see sard.js api

export function MyPlugin(): Plugin {
  return {
    name: 'my-plugin',

    server(server) {
      // middleware
      server.use((req, res, next) => {
        next();
      });
      // handling
      server.get('/', (req, res) => {
        res.end('hello');
      });
    },
  };
}

# Typescript

export interface Plugin {
  name: string;
  transform?: (id: string, code: string) => PluginOutput | Promise<PluginOutput>;
  server?: (server: Server) => void;
}

api-server.md.html:
# Server

Prext use own library called sard.js. It was because of speed and weight.

If you want information of sard.js, visit here.

# Prext()

It creates a core server.

import { Prext } from 'prext';

const server = await Prext({
  /* config */
});

// middleware

server.use((req, res, next) => {
  next();
});

server.get('/', (req, res) => {
  res.end('Hello World!');
});

server.listen(3000, () => {});

See API - documentation

# handles()

# Routes

import { handles } from 'prext/server';
import { server } from 'sard.js';

const app = server();

const routes = [
  {
    file: '/',
    m: {
      get(req, res) {
        res.end('Hello World');
      },
    },
    modulePath: '',
    type: 'module',
  },
];

app.all('*', (req, res) => {
  handles(req, res, routes);
});

app.listen(3000);

import { SardRequest, SardResponse } from 'sard.js';

export function handles(
  req: SardRequest,
  res: SardResponse,
  routes: {
    file: string;
    m: any;
    modulePath: string;
    type: string;
  }[]
);

getting-started.md.html:
# Getting Started

# Using tool

You can create prext application easily with create-prext.

  1. Download Template
> npx create-prext
  1. Install Dependencies
> npm i # install dependencies
  1. Run!
> npm dev # start app

# Manual Installation

You can also add prext to a project that already exists.

Enter the command below:

> npm install --save-dev prext

Add the configuration file (prext.config.ts).

// prext.config.ts
import { defineConfig } from 'prext/config';

export default defineConfig({
  // options
});

guide-build.md.html:
# Build

You can export your backend application!

Although you didn't install dependencies or removed pages by mistake, you can start server with this feature.

This feature creates a ready-to-run javascript file like an executable (such as exe).

# Before Build

You have to update configure file (prext.config.js or prext.config.ts).

- import { defineConfig } from "prext";
+ import { defineConfig } from "prext/config";

This step helps reduce the size of the output.

# Usage

Run:

> prext export

will create dist/index.js. And check if it works well.

> node dist/index.js

Then, remove node_modules and pages!

> rimraf node_modules
> rimraf pages

Check again if it works.

> node dist/index.js

# Usage

> prext export -h

  Usage
    $ prext export

  Export Prext Server

  Options
    --help, -h       Displays help information.
    --version, -v    Displays current version.
    --config, -c     Provide config file path.

# Warning

This feature doesn't support html and middlewares.

Middlewares and html have been supported since ^0.0.10! 🎉🎉

guide-page.md.html:
# $page

$page variable provides data of page.

Example:

export const $page = {};

# path

Provide custom path.

// pages/my-about.ts
export function get(req, res) {
  res.end('About Page');
}

export const $page = {
  path: '/about',
};

# before/after

A function that is run before/after processing request.

export const $page = {
  before(req, res) {
    console.log(`new request: ${req.params.slug}`);
  }
  after(req, res) {
    console.log("Done!");
  }
}

middlewares.md.html:
# Middlewares

# Usage

// middlewares/message.ts
import { Middleware } from 'prext';

export const Message: Middleware = (req, res, next) => {
  (req as any).message = 'Hello World!';
  next();
};

// pages/index.ts
import { PrextRequest, PrextResponse } from 'prext';

export function get(req: PrextRequest, res: PrextResponse) {
  res.end((req as any).message);
}

# Regists

Add them to config.middlewares.

// prext.config.ts

import { Message } from './middlewares/message';

export default defineConfig({
  middlewares: [Message],
  // ...
});

# Auto Mode

autoMiddlewareMode is a experimental feature.

To use auto middleware mode, edit config value.

// middlewares/message.ts
import { Middleware } from 'prext';

const Message: Middleware = (req, res, next) => {
  (req as any).message = 'Hello World!';

  next();
};

// export as default

export default Message;

// prext.config.ts
export default defineConfig({
  allowAutoMiddlewares: true,
  middlewareDirectory: 'middlewares',
});

pkg-create-prext-app.md.html:
# craete prext app

github, npm

create-prext-app is a tool that helps you create prext app easily.

This package is no longer maintained. Use create-prext instead.

# Usage

> npx create-prext-app my-app --with-typescript

# Options

# with typescript

To clone typescript template, add --with-typescript flag.

# with javascript

To clone javascript template, add --with-javascript flag.

# react

React Template is only available in create-prext-app.

To clone react template, add --react flag.

# All Commands

npx create-prext-app -h

  Usage
    $ prext <command> [options]

  Commands

  Options
    --help, -h           Displays help information.
    --version, -v        Displays current version.
    --with-javascript    Javascript template (default true)
    --with-typescript    Typescript template
    --react              Prexty (react) template

  Run `prext <command> --help` for more information.

pkg-create-prext.md.html:
# create prext

github, npm

a Tool creating prext app

create-prext-app is no longer maintained.

> npx create-prext

? Project name: my-app
? Directory: backend
? Template: typescript

Cloning Templates...

  $ cd my-app
  $ npm i
  $ npm run dev

Happy Hacking!

# Usage

> npx create-prext

pkg-kit.md.html:
# @prext/plugin-kit

This package is a test plugin. Not for production.

This package has a lot of bugs.

# Installation

> npm install --save-dev @prext/plugin-kit

# Usage

import { defineConfig } from 'prext/config';
import { kit } from '@prext/plugin-kit';

export default defineConfig({
  plugins: [kit()],
});

pkg-prext-analyst.md.html:
# prext analyst

github, npm

prext-analyst analyzes your project.

This package is no longer maintained.

# Installation

> yarn add -D prext prext-analyst

# Usage

"scripts": {
+  "analyze": "prext analyze"
}

> yarn run analyze

Output example:

1. /pages/about => /about (../node_modules/.prext/my-about.w90mpmogft.js)
2. /pages/users/$id.ts => /users/:id (../node_modules/.prext/$id.1p6ogz2ggyo.js)

Dist Directory - /node_modules/.prext
Cache File - /node_modules/.prext/cache.json
Size - 4437 byte

2 pages found.

prexty is a plugin for prext that makes it possible to use a frontend language.

pkg-sard.md.html:
# Sard.js

github, npm

Sard.js is a tiny Http Server Module. It was made for speed and size.

no longer update. use osik instead

# Features

  • Very tiny. (10.5 kB (in v0.1.1))
  • Typescript supported
  • Lightning fast

# Installation

> npm i --save-dev sard.js

import { server } from 'sard.js';

const app = server(/* config */);

app.get('/', (req, res) => {
  res.end('Hello World!');
});

app.listen(3000);

# Error Handling

app.get('/', (req, res) => {
  res.end('Hello World!');
});

app.use((req, res, next) => {
  res.statusCode = 404;
  res.end('page not found');
});

# APIs

Table

  • server
  • pathToRegexp

# server

  • Types: server(options: Sard): Server
const { server } = require('sard.js');

const app = server();

# server.use

  • Types: use(...fn: HandlerType[]): this

add middlewares.

app.use((req, res, next) => {
  next();
});

or you can add middlewares in a different way:

  • source
app.addHandler('all', '*', (req, res, next) => {
  next();
});

# server.[METHOD]

app.all((req, res) => {});
app.get((req, res) => {});
app.post((req, res) => {});
app.delete((req, res) => {});

# server.listen

  • Type: listen(port: number, ...args: any[]): this

# pathToRegexp

require('sard.js').pathToRegexp('/about', true);
// { params: [], pattern: /^\/about(?=$|\/)/i }
require('sard.js').pathToRegexp('/user/:id', true);
// { params: [ 'id' ], pattern: /^\/user\/([^/]+?)(?=$|\/)/i }

# Types

source

routing.md.html:
# Routing

Prext.js automatically generates routes based on your file tree of pages.

.
├─ pages
│  ├─ user
│  │  └─ $id.ts
│  ├─ users.ts
│  └─ index.ts
├─ prext.config.ts
└─ package.json

will be

["/", "/users", "/users/:id"]

More examples:

/pages/index.ts => /
/pages/dashboard.ts => /dashboard
/pages/foo/bar.ts => /foo/bar
/pages/user/$user.ts => /user/:user

# Custom Path

If you don't like routes based on filename, just export $page!

export const $page = {
  path: '/foo/bar',
};

# Route Parameters

You can access the current page parameters by req.params.

// pages/user/$id.ts

import { PrextRequest, PrextResponse } from 'prext';

export function get(req: PrextRequest, res: PrextResponse) {
  res.json({ id: req.params.id });
}

# Method

Exports functions corresponding get, post, delete etc (http verbs)

// get
export function get(req, res) {}
// post
export function post(req, res) {}
// etc...

# request

Prext Server is based on node:http module.

reference: http.req

# req.params

Page Parameters.

  • type: any
  • example: /item/$id => req.params.id
export function get(req, res) {
  res.end(`item: ${req.params.id}!`);
}

# req.query

Page Querystring.

  • type: object
  • example: /abc?foo=bar => req.query.foo

# response

Prext Server is based on node:http module.

reference: http.res

# res.json

Send json data.

export function get(req, res) {
  res.json({ id: 1 });
}

# res.end

Send data

export function get(req, res) {
  res.end('Hello World!');
}

# res.send

Send data

same as "req.end"

# res.setHeader

Set header

# res.status

Set status

  • added: 1.0.0-beta.1
export function get(req, res) {
  res.status(200).end('Hello World!');
}

# 404 page

This Feature has been supported since v0.1.0.

You can set 404 page with config.error.

export default defineConfig({
  error(req, res) {
    // ...
  },
});

# Parameters in HTML

You cannot access the current page parameters. - (#1)

typescript.md.html:
# Typescript

Prext fully supports typescript. Most of tests (while development) were run with typescript. Thus, using typescript is recommended.

# Using create-prext-app

> npx create-prext-app my-ts-app --with-typescript

# Using create-prext

Select Typescript Option

> npx create-prext

? Project name: my-app
? Directory: backend
? Template: typescript

# Migrantion Javascript to Typescript

// pages/index.ts

+ import { PrextRequest, PrextResponse } from 'prext';

- module.exports.get = function(req, res) {
+ export function get(req: PrextRequest, res: PrextResponse) {

  res.end("I love typescript!");
}

rename prext.config.js to prext.config.ts

// prext.config.js => prext.config.ts
- const { defineConfig } = require("prext");
+ import { defineConfig } from "prext";

- module.exports = defineConfig({});
+ export default defineConfig({});

what-is-prext.md.html:
# What is Prext

🛰️ Prext is a backend framework for Node.js.

# Features

  • 🚧 File-based routing. Prext.js creates routes automatically with filenames. - see more
  • 🚀 Server Reload. You don't have to restart server to apply changes.
  • ✅ Typescript Supported. - see more
  • ⚡ Lightning fast. Prext uses esbuild as javascript loader.

# Introduction

Prext.js (previous + next) is a node.js backend framework inspired by next. This project aims to be the lightest Nodejs backend framework.

# Why you made it?

Express or Node HTTP module is a awesome backend package, but it is so bothering to set routes.

To solve this problem I created this package.
